io.dazraf.vertx.futures

Interface FutureChain<T,Derived extends FutureChain<T,Derived>>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The result type of the future
    Derived - The type of class that actually implements this interface
    All Superinterfaces:
    io.vertx.core.AsyncResult<T>, io.vertx.core.Future<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    FutureChain1, FutureChain2, FutureChain3, FutureChainImpl, FutureChainX

    public interface FutureChain<T,Derived extends FutureChain<T,Derived>>
extends io.vertx.core.Future<T>
    This is the primary interface for working with these futures. It provides the following method categories:
    • Factories: these are in the form when(Future), when(Future, Future) etc
    • Chaining methods: these allow chaining of functions that return Future. They are in the form then(Function), then2(Function) etc
    • Event handlers: onSuccess(java.util.function.Consumer<T>) onFail(java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Throwable>) onComplete(java.util.function.Consumer<io.vertx.core.AsyncResult<T>>). Exceptions from these handlers affect the computation graph. There are also specialised forms of these that can de-structure composite futures. More about this later.
    • Peek handlers: peekSuccess(Consumer) peekFail(Consumer) peekComplete(Consumer) Exceptions from these handlers do not affect the computation graph. There are also specialised forms of these that can de-structure composite futures. More about this later.
    • map functions.
    • ifFailed(Function) for conditional handling of flow when a future has failed.
    It provides a set of factory methods: when(Future)

      • Fields inherited from interface io.vertx.core.Future
